title: Get started
text: SEMs ubiquitous social sciences, psychology, ecology, fields. INLAvaan package provides user-friendly interface fitting Bayesian SEMs using Integrated Nested Laplace Approximations (INLA, Rue, Martino, Chopin 2009). vignette guide basics using INLAvaan fit simple SEM. begin make sure installed INLAvaan package GitHub running commands .
code: # Run this if you have not yet installed INLAvaan install.packages("pak") pak::pak("haziqj/INLAvaan")  # Load all libraries for this example library(INLAvaan) library(tidyverse) library(lavaan)

title: Get started
text: motivate use SEMs, consider introductory example Song Lee (2012): poorer glycemic control lead greater severity kidney disease? observe three indicators glycemic control (y1y_1, y2y_2, y3y_3) three indicators kidney disease severity (y4y_4, y5y_5, y6y_6).  Rather fitting separate regression models indicator, SEM allows us model relationship latent constructs , providing clearer coherent representation underlying processes. hypothesised SEM illustrated figure :

title: Get started
text: two-factor SEM described , easy simulate data using lavaan package . code : code , note true values parameters, including factor loadings Λ\Lambda, regression coefficient β\beta two latent variables, well residual latent variances Θ\Theta Ψ\Psi respectively.

title: Get started
text: Now simulated data, can fit SEM using INLAvaan. model syntax similar lavaan, making easy specify model. details model syntax, refer lavaan website. INLAvaan provides mirror functions main model fitting functions lavaan: acfa() mirrors lavaan::cfa() confirmatory factor analysis; asem() mirrors lavaan::sem() structural equation models; agrowth() mirrors lavaan::growth() latent growth curve models. code fit SEM model : INLAvaan computes approximation posterior density way Laplace approximation (Tierney, Kass, Kadane 1989). joint mode Hessian needs computed, gives Gaussian distribution joint posterior parameters. default method optimisation stats::nlminb(), optimisers can used specifying optim_method = "ucminf" ucminf package optim_method = "optim" call stats::optim() function method "BFGS". , marginal posterior distributions parameter can obtained one several ways, including 1) Skew normal fitting (marginal_method = "skewnorm", default method, see Chiuchiolo, Van Niekerk, Rue 2023); 2) Two-piece asymmetric Gaussian fitting (marginal_method = "asymgaus", see Martins et al. 2013); 3) Direct marginalisation joint Gaussian posterior (marginal_method = "marggaus"); 4) Sampling joint Gaussian posterior (marginal_method = "sampling"). marginal posterior distributions obtained, can use compute derived quantities interest via copula sampling. posterior predictive p-values (Gelman, Meng, Stern 1996) Deviance Information Criterion (DIC, Spiegelhalter et al. 2002) computed way. Often, posterior sampling takes longer model fitting , number samples can controlled via nsamp argument (default nsamp = 1000) can skipped altoghether (test = "none").
code: mod <- "   eta1 =~ y1 + y2 + y3   eta2 =~ y4 + y5 + y6   eta2 ~ eta1 " fit <- asem(mod, dat) #> ℹ Using MVN log-likelihood. #> ℹ Finding posterior mode. #> ✔ Finding posterior mode. [113ms] #>  #> ℹ Computing the Hessian. #> ✔ Computing the Hessian. [181ms] #>  #> ℹ Performing VB correction. #> ✔ Performing VB correction. [217ms] #>  #> ℹ Using skew normal approximation. #> ⠙ Fitting skew normal to 0/13 marginals. #> ✔ Fitting skew normal to 13/13 marginals. [632ms] #>  #> ⠙ Computing ppp and DIC. #> ⠹ Computing ppp and DIC. #> ✔ Computing ppp and DIC. [1.5s] #>

title: Get started
text: resulting object class INLAvaan, subclass lavaan objects. result, methods work lavaan objects also work INLAvaan objects. common ones probably coef() summary(). ’s possible request posterior medians modes summary output specifying postmedian = TRUE postmode = TRUE summary() function. Predicted values latent variables can obtained using predict() function. done sampling posterior distributions latent variables given observed data. future, function also allow --sample predictions also retrieve predictions observed variables. S3 object summary method provides posterior means credible intervals latent variables. Alternatively, user welcome perform summary statistics list posterior samples returned predict(). simple plot method provided view marginal posterior distributions parameters. vertical lines indicate posterior mode.

title: Get started
text: addition several global fit indices (.e. PPP, DIC), possible compare models way Bayes factors using compare() function. function takes two INLAvaan objects computes Bayes factor using Laplace approximations marginal likelihoods. note, several criticisms use Bayes factors model comparison, particularly context SEMs (Tendeiro Kiers 2019; Schad et al. 2023). blavaan package able implement WAICs LOOs alternative model comparison metrics, hopefully also implemented future versions INLAvaan.

title: Get started
text: INLAvaan package uses prior specification syntax blavaan (Merkle Rosseel 2018; Merkle et al. 2021), detailed . Essentially, two ways set priors model parameters: 1) Globally parameters certain type (e.g., factor loadings, regression coefficients, etc.); 2) Individually specific parameters model syntax. default global priors derived blavaan: Note , INLAvaan uses SRS decomposition variance matrices, consequently places priors correlations instead covariances. , instead wished set global priors, say Gamma distribution variances instead standard deviations (default), following: set individual priors specific parameters, can model syntax . instance, set normal prior mean 1 standard deviation 3 factor loading y3 eta1, normal prior mean 0 standard deviation 0.5 regression coefficient eta1 eta2, specify model follows:
code: blavaan::dpriors() #>                nu             alpha            lambda              beta  #>    "normal(0,32)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"  #>             theta               psi               rho             ibpsi  #> "gamma(1,.5)[sd]" "gamma(1,.5)[sd]"       "beta(1,1)" "wishart(3,iden)"  #>               tau  #>   "normal(0,1.5)" DP <- blavaan::dpriors(theta = "gamma(1,1)", psi = "gamma(1,1)") DP #>                nu             alpha            lambda              beta  #>    "normal(0,32)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"  #>             theta               psi               rho             ibpsi  #>      "gamma(1,1)"      "gamma(1,1)"       "beta(1,1)" "wishart(3,iden)"  #>               tau  #>   "normal(0,1.5)" ## fit <- asem(mod, dat, dpriors = DP)  # not run mod <- "   eta1 =~ y1 + y2 + prior('normal(1,3)')*y3   eta2 =~ y4 + y5 + y6   eta2 ~ prior('normal(0,.5)')*eta1 " ## fit <- asem(mod, dat)  # not run

what: Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis using INLA
title: Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis using INLA
text: Efficient approximate Bayesian inference Structural Equation Models. Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods remain gold standard exact Bayesian inference, can prohibitively slow iterative model development. INLAvaan offers rapid alternative latent variable analysis, delivering Bayesian results (near) speed frequentist estimators. achieves custom, ground-implementation Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA), engineered specifically lavaan modelling framework.

title: Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis using INLA
text: INLAvaan designed fit seamlessly existing workflow. familiar (b)lavaan syntax, can begin using INLAvaan immediately. first impression package, consider canonical example SEM applied Industrialisation Political Democracy data set Bollen (1989)1:

title: Fit an Approximate Bayesian Confirmatory Factor Analysis Model — acfa
text: model description user-specified model. Typically, model     described using lavaan model syntax. See     model.syntax information. Alternatively,     parameter table (eg. output lavParTable() function) also     accepted. data optional data frame containing observed variables used     model. variables declared ordered factors, lavaan     treat ordinal variables. dp Default prior distributions different types     parameters, typically result call dpriors().     See dpriors() help file information. estimator estimator used. Currently "ML" (maximum likelihood) supported. marginal_method method approximating marginal posterior distributions. Options include "skewnorm" (skew normal), "asymgaus" (two-piece asymmetric Gaussian), "marggaus" (marginalising Laplace approximation), "sampling" (sampling joint Laplace approximation). nsamp number samples draw sampling-based approaches (including posterior sampling model fit indices). test Character indicating whether compute posterior fit indices. Defaults "standard". Change "none" skip computations. marginal_correction type correction use fitting skew normal two-piece Gaussian marginals. "hessian" computes full Hessian-based correction (slow), "shortcut" (default) computes diagonals, "none" applies correction. sn_fit_logthresh log-threshold fitting skew normal. Points log-posterior drop threshold (relative maximum) excluded fit. Defaults -6. sn_fit_temp Temperature parameter fitting skew normal. NA, temperature included optimisation skew normal fit. control list control parameters optimiser. verbose Logical indicating whether print progress messages. debug Logical indicating whether return debug information. add_priors Logical indicating whether include prior densities posterior computation. optim_method optimisation method use finding posterior mode. Options include "nlminb" (default), "ucminf", "optim" (BFGS). numerical_grad Logical indicating whether use numerical gradients optimisation. ... Additional arguments passed lavaan::lavaan model fitting function.

title: Fit an Approximate Bayesian Structural Equation Model — asem
text: model description user-specified model. Typically, model     described using lavaan model syntax. See     model.syntax information. Alternatively,     parameter table (eg. output lavParTable() function) also     accepted. data optional data frame containing observed variables used     model. variables declared ordered factors, lavaan     treat ordinal variables. dp Default prior distributions different types     parameters, typically result call dpriors().     See dpriors() help file information. estimator estimator used. Currently "ML" (maximum likelihood) supported. marginal_method method approximating marginal posterior distributions. Options include "skewnorm" (skew normal), "asymgaus" (two-piece asymmetric Gaussian), "marggaus" (marginalising Laplace approximation), "sampling" (sampling joint Laplace approximation). nsamp number samples draw sampling-based approaches (including posterior sampling model fit indices). test Character indicating whether compute posterior fit indices. Defaults "standard". Change "none" skip computations. marginal_correction type correction use fitting skew normal two-piece Gaussian marginals. "hessian" computes full Hessian-based correction (slow), "shortcut" (default) computes diagonals, "none" applies correction. sn_fit_logthresh log-threshold fitting skew normal. Points log-posterior drop threshold (relative maximum) excluded fit. Defaults -6. sn_fit_temp Temperature parameter fitting skew normal. NA, temperature included optimisation skew normal fit. control list control parameters optimiser. verbose Logical indicating whether print progress messages. debug Logical indicating whether return debug information. add_priors Logical indicating whether include prior densities posterior computation. optim_method optimisation method use finding posterior mode. Options include "nlminb" (default), "ucminf", "optim" (BFGS). numerical_grad Logical indicating whether use numerical gradients optimisation. ... Additional arguments passed lavaan::lavaan model fitting function.

title: Compare Bayesian Models Fitted with INLAvaan — compare
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # Model comparison on multigroup analysis (measurement invariance)   HS.model <- "     visual  =~ x1 + x2 + x3     textual =~ x4 + x5 + x6     speed   =~ x7 + x8 + x9   "   utils::data("HolzingerSwineford1939", package = "lavaan")    # Configural invariance   fit1 <- acfa(HS.model, data = HolzingerSwineford1939, group = "school")    # Weak invariance   fit2 <- acfa(     HS.model,     data = HolzingerSwineford1939,     group = "school",     group.equal = "loadings"   )    # Strong invariance   fit3 <- acfa(     HS.model,     data = HolzingerSwineford1939,     group = "school",     group.equal = c("intercepts", "loadings")   )    # Compare models   compare(fit1, fit2, fit3) } # }

text: skew normal fitting function uses weighted least squares approach fit log-density evaluations provided y points x. weights set density evaluations raised power temperature parameter k. somewhat interpretation finding skew normal fit minimises Kullback-Leibler divergence true density . R-INLA, C code implementation translated can found .

title: Fit a skew normal distribution to log-density evaluations — fit_skew_normal
code: library(sn) #> Loading required package: stats4 #>  #> Attaching package: ‘sn’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     sd library(tidyr) library(ggplot2)  logdens <- function(x) dgamma(x, shape = 3, rate = 1, log = TRUE)  x_grid <- seq(0.1, 8, length.out = 21) y_log <- sapply(x_grid, logdens) y_log <- y_log - max(y_log) # normalise to have maximum at zero  res <- fit_skew_normal(x_grid, y_log, temp = 10) unlist(res) #>         xi      omega      alpha       logC          k        rsq  #>  0.8424454  2.5392261  3.3105054  1.3324227 10.0000000  0.9988780   plot_df <-   pivot_longer(     tibble(       x = seq(0.1, 8, length.out = 200),       truth = exp(logdens(x)),       approx = dsnorm(x, xi = res$xi, omega = res$omega, alpha = res$alpha)     ),     cols = c("truth", "approx"),     names_to = "type",     values_to = "density"   )  ggplot() +   # truth as filled area   geom_area(     data = subset(plot_df, type == "truth"),     aes(x, density, fill = "Truth"),     alpha = 0.38   ) +   # approx as blue line   geom_line(     data = subset(plot_df, type == "approx"),     aes(x = x, y = density, col = "SN Approx."),     linewidth = 1   ) +   scale_fill_manual(name = NULL, values = "#131516") +   scale_colour_manual(name = NULL, values = "#00A6AA") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "top")

title: Fit an Approximate Bayesian Latent Variable Model — inlavaan
text: model description user-specified model. Typically, model     described using lavaan model syntax. See     model.syntax information. Alternatively,     parameter table (eg. output lavParTable() function) also     accepted. data optional data frame containing observed variables used     model. variables declared ordered factors, lavaan     treat ordinal variables. model.type Set model type: possible values     "cfa", "sem" "growth". may affect     starting values computed, may used alter terminology     used summary output, layout path diagrams     based fitted lavaan object. dp Default prior distributions different types     parameters, typically result call dpriors().     See dpriors() help file information. estimator estimator used. Currently "ML" (maximum likelihood) supported. vb_correction Logical indicating whether apply variational Bayes correction posterior mean vector estimates. Defaults TRUE. marginal_method method approximating marginal posterior distributions. Options include "skewnorm" (skew normal), "asymgaus" (two-piece asymmetric Gaussian), "marggaus" (marginalising Laplace approximation), "sampling" (sampling joint Laplace approximation). marginal_correction type correction use fitting skew normal two-piece Gaussian marginals. "hessian" computes full Hessian-based correction (slow), "shortcut" (default) computes diagonals, "none" applies correction. nsamp number samples draw sampling-based approaches (including posterior sampling model fit indices). test Character indicating whether compute posterior fit indices. Defaults "standard". Change "none" skip computations. sn_fit_logthresh log-threshold fitting skew normal. Points log-posterior drop threshold (relative maximum) excluded fit. Defaults -6. sn_fit_temp Temperature parameter fitting skew normal. NA, temperature included optimisation skew normal fit. control list control parameters optimiser. verbose Logical indicating whether print progress messages. debug Logical indicating whether return debug information. add_priors Logical indicating whether include prior densities posterior computation. optim_method optimisation method use finding posterior mode. Options include "nlminb" (default), "ucminf", "optim" (BFGS). numerical_grad Logical indicating whether use numerical gradients optimisation. ... Additional arguments passed lavaan::lavaan model fitting function.

title: INLAvaan (development version)
text: Support lavaan 0.6-21. Implemented variational Bayes mean correction posterior marginals.

title: INLAvaan 0.2
text: INLAvaan rewritten ground specifically SEM models. new version call R-INLA directly, instead uses core approximation ideas fit SEM models efficiently. Features restricted normal likelihoods continuous observations now. Support models lavaan/blavaan can fit, including CFA, SEM, growth curve models. Support multigroup analysis. Added PPP DIC model fit indices. Added prior specification model parameters. Added support fixed values parameter constraints. Initial CRAN submission.

title: INLAvaan 0.1
text: Used rgeneric functionality R-INLA implement basic SEM framework.
